qas.question: What trait does Old English possess that Modern English lacks?
Along with the nominative, genitive, dative and instrumental, what case did Old English possess?
The Modern English ending -'s is derived from what ending in Old English?
In Old English, noun endings vary on what basis?
What kind of diversity is found in Modern English?

plausible_answers.text: the forms of a few pronouns

qas.question: What were examples of morphology in Old English and Old Norse?

context: Unlike Modern English, Old English is a language rich in <a0_0><b4_0>morphological diversity<b4_0/><a0_0/>. It maintains several distinct cases: the nominative, <a1_0>accusative<a1_0/>, genitive, dative and (vestigially) instrumental. The only remnants of this system in Modern English are in <b5_0>the forms of a few pronouns<b5_0/> (such as I/me/mine, she/her, who/whom/whose) and in the possessive ending -'s, which derives from the old (masculine and neuter) genitive ending <a2_0>-es<a2_0/>. In Old English, however, nouns and their modifying words take appropriate endings depending on <a3_0>their case<a3_0/>.
